definitions.definition: the organ inside the head that controls movement, thought, memory and feeling

examples.text: The **human brain** is a complex organ.
My tired brain couldn't cope with such a complex problem.
She was found to have sustained a **brain injury**.
**brain cells/tissue**
a **brain tumour/haemorrhage/aneurysm**
Sometimes the doctor will also do a brain scan.
brain surgery
He had a brain scan to search for possible damage.
He was found to have a blood clot on his brain.
His brain reeled as he realized the implication of his dismissal.
The left brain controls the right-hand side of the body.
The stopping distance includes the time taken for the brain to register the need to stop.
Electrodes were used to measure brain activity during sleep.
Fruit eating primates have relatively larger brains than those that eat leaves.
We want to halve stillbirths and brain injuries in newborns in the next five years.
She died of a brain tumour.
a device to measure brain activity during sleep
There has been some loss of brain function.
She is one of the country's leading brain surgeons.
The scan apparently showed no damage to the brain.

definitions.definition: the brain of an animal, eaten as food

examples.text: sheep’s brains

definitions.definition: the ability to learn quickly and think about things in a logical and intelligent way

examples.text: It doesn't take much brain to work out that both stories can't be true.
Teachers spotted that he had a good brain at an early age.
You need brains as well as brawn *(= intelligence as well as strength)* to do this job.
She has a good brain for mathematics.
Jack's got the brain to realize that the money won't last forever.
They relied on brains rather than brawn.
She must have inherited her mother's brains.
It's important to keep your brain ticking over.
one of the best scientific brains in the country
We have the best scientific brains in the country working on this.

definitions.definition: the most intelligent person in a particular group; the person who is responsible for thinking of and organizing something

examples.text: He's always been the brains of the family.
The band's drummer is the brains behind their latest venture.
He was the brains behind the robberies.

definitions.definition: to think very hard about something for a long time

examples.text: I’ve been beating my brains out all weekend to get this script written.

definitions.definition: to kill yourself/somebody by shooting yourself/them in the head

examples.text: He put a gun to his head and threatened to blow his brains out.
While cleaning his shotgun he had accidentally blown his own brains out.
I had to cudgel my brains to remember her name.

definitions.definition: to think about something all the time, especially in a way that is annoying

examples.text: She's got football on the brain.

definitions.definition: to ask somebody a lot of questions about something because they know more about the subject than you do

examples.text: I need to pick your brains: what can you tell me about credit unions?

definitions.definition: to think very hard or for a long time about something

examples.text: She racked her brains, trying to remember exactly what she had said.
We racked our brains but we couldn't come up with a solution.

wordOrigin: Old English brægen, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch brein.
